reviewText: Gothic II is a gigantic game in a small world. The trick that the devs pulled to make the game seem so enormous was to make use of absolutely every nook and cranny on the map. Most of these places aren't even relevant to the main story; you can plow through the game several times over and still stumble across something new hidden in an easily missed gap between rocks or behind a waterfall at the bottom of a deep valley. Since the game doesn't throw powerful items or experience at you like lots of the loot-fest RPGs out there, the (usually) small rewards secreted away across the island are always satisfying to discover. This and the fact that the game is largely loading screen- and objective marker-free makes the whole world feel alive and supremely explorable. Just be careful; the game will hold your hand for a grand total of five seconds before booting you into a world where all of the local fauna have it out for you and will absolutely WRECK you if you aren't familiar with the somewhat clunky combat system. It gets easier later on but the challenge is always there. Don't be scared though; the danger just makes exploring that much more rewarding.

reviewText:
Don't look at my play time. I bought the game just so I can write a review.
What? Yep.. I did.

For the last 12 years I played Gothic franchise. Every winter, when the weather goes bad outside, I have to follow my tradition of playing one of the Gothic games. For 12 years...

If you read this far and you never played this game but you call yourself a RPG fan, then do yourself a favor and buy it!
Buy it and play it for at least 1 hour. This is how long it will take you to get used to the controls and to  the open-world-no-hand-holding ideology.

If I could wrap up the review in some simple words, they would be: Gothic = immersion.

This is a common scene that you will find in Gothic 2:
Heavy grey sky, raining. It's night and you see the soldiers gathering around a camp fire and chat. One of them even starts roasting the carcass of a hunted animal over the fire, preparing the dinner. The merchants sit down in front of big water pipes and relax, smoking different types of weeds. An owl can be heard in the forest close to the camp while through the trees, you can see some Scavangers going to sleep for the night. You decide to also sit on a log and enjoy some socialization time after all the fighting and hunting done over the day.

Pros:
- solid story with deep lore, a mix between religion, mysticism and politics.
- unprecedented AI behavior! Seriously, this franchise is 16 years old but even today the Ai scripting, behavior and combat is unmatched in any other RPG. Sure some other games excel in certain segments of AI implementation, but overall, you wont see a more vivid and realistic AI.
- a true open world. If you see something in the distance, you will most likely be able to reach and explore it. There are many level designers that can provide good content with a large world, but only geniuses can make every inch of a small world filled with content.
- your actions matter. Stealing from someones house or chest? Bad idea. Beating up some important NPC that has many friends and connections? Really bad idea. Betraying a whole faction and be responsible for their deaths? Awesome!
- a very natural and diverse quest system. Make friends, make enemies, steal, hijack, frame some or prove the innocence of others in order to unlock more quests.
- choose your path. This is not Skyrim or Mass Effect. Once you chosen a faction, there is no turning back! Playing each faction it's basically a separate playthrough. This is how much the game changes depending on the path taken!
- absolutely beautiful soundtrack, realistic nature sounds and good voice over.

Cons:
- somewhat awkward control scheme, but it's consistent! Once you learn to handle it, the controls feel smooth.
- outdated graphics. D'oh! 16 years old engine.
- almost no hand holding. No flashing quest marks over NPC heads, no minimap, no pointers all over the screen (probably this is also a reason why the game is so immersive... nothing to distract you from the actual game)
- high difficulty in combat, but not unfair!
- access violation error for some systems, that can be easily solved by running the game in Windows XP SP2 compatibility mode + Administrator rights.

By today standards the game is 7 / 10. But, by taking a look at the game industry today... this game is a 10/10 from head to toes. This is a rough gem that deserves a chance to be discovered.

Piranha Bytes, thank you for creating Gothic series. With all my heart, thank you!

reviewText:
Gothic II. What a great, rewarding and exciting game.

After a series of events, you break out of the colony with friends you made there. Freedom, right? No.
You weren't the only one to break out. Most bandits got out too and started to rob and murder innocent citizens of Khorinis. People see you as a nobody yet again, but slowly you gain respect and eventually become a respected man across the island, saving Khorinis from an evil force that's about to struck it.

Gameplay is improved in many ways over the first game. Controls don't feel stiff. Combat is fun and never gets old: you hold LMB and use WASD to swing your weapons in different directions, no button mashing involved.
You can join different factions: Paladins, Mercenaries and Mages. All of them are very different and have a lot of faction-related quests, so it's worth it to beat the game multiple times.
You visit a lot of places in the game: the main island of Khorinis, the colony from the first game (which is now abandoned, grey and full of orcs at every step that'll murder you in mere seconds), swampy Jarkendar from the expansion and some other minor ones. All locations are unique and different, NPCs have their own chores and the game feels alive. I'll be honest, I got immersed. I spent hundreds of hours wandering around and finding cool quests and secrets.

Gothic II is my favourite RPG and I beat it many times. It's the experience I will never forget.

reviewText:
Back in 2001, a wonderful RPG named Gothic 1 hit the markets. It’s truly an open world adventure that has absolutely no hand holding. Brutal yet fair, it’s not for everyone. Personally, I enjoyed the game despite its weird user-interface. Yet in hindsight, it actually served well enough as, in parts, can be quite immersive. Two years later, and to my surprise, Gothic 2 hit the markets. This game took all the strengths of Gothic 1 and enhanced it a hundred times – so much it makes Gothic 1 looks like a tech demo. Yet there are some slight weaknesses like the user interface however it’s minor comparing to what the game can offer overall.

Depending what you want from this game determines the length of time to complete. For me, I tried to complete everything possible from picking up every plant to completing all of the quests possible. Even I used to walk option to explore any new areas so it took me around 100 plus hours to complete all six chapters. And the beauty of this is that, the game had a really decent pace to it – other words, it didn’t feel like a chore at all. That said, Gothic 2 is a game that RPG players will be proud of. It has all the elements of a proper RPG ranging from interacting to combat to exploration. The UI still needs tailoring however, after a little practice, it’s passible and won’t cause too much grief. An absolute must for any lovers of RPGs yet newcomers will find this a little too daunting.

Full review here: http://www.gamespot.com/gothic-ii/user-reviews/2200-12659434/

Gothic 2 is a fascinating survival game based on exploration, discovery and choices.
You have to live off what you can find, you cant afford to buy anything for a good while, coin is scarce and prices are high.

You can also screw up in many different ways, nothing is handed to you (typical for all Pyranha Bytes games).
Graphics are dated by today's standards but they are so well done that after a while they start looking quite good, they grow on you.
The combat system can be very awkward, confusing and annoying at first, i know it was for me, but once you begin to figure it out, it gets quite rewarding.
The survival feeling is there, anything can kill you in a hit or two, you start with the shirt on your back a knife and a branch as your weapons.
You can find strange and interesting characters that offer you choices, or you can miss them if you rush, doesnt matter because whatever path you chose the journey will be worthwhile in different ways.

This is by far the best game you will ever play. I have personally never played a better RPG. I will now go into detail about why this is the best way to spend your money on a game.

First of all the story: If you have played Gothic 1 you will get to meet many of your old friends again. I personally played Gothic 1 after Gothic 2, and it didn't matter alot. Most of the dialogues give you the option to navigate around having met them before (in Gothic 1), but I surely do encourage you to play Gothic 1 before since it will greatly improve your enjoyment when meeting your old brothers again. The story continues perfectly with twists and new problem and adventures to explore. Honestly, the story is probably the best thing about this game, it just makes you love the characters, form realtionships, go on quests together and knock on baddies heads.

Now to the Wolrd and its design: Epic. That's the only word you need to describe Gothic 2s' worlds. Piranha Bytes has the best team when it comes to creating maps. Every inch is used to its maximum potential, there are a big variety of different locations, each one unique and special in some way. In every corner there is a secret to discover or a unknown Boss-Mob to defeat. In Gothic 2s' worlds every step feels special, there is always something you didn't notice on your first walk along a path.

Furthermore to the gameplay: Gothic isn't a game that babysits you through your playtime. You get thrown into the cold water (literally in Gothic 1 :) ), noone is there to show you where to go for a quest, no markers on your UI, no markers on the maps, nothing. It just feels like you are really in that world, wandering around not knowing where to go or who you will meet behind the next turn. It surely is a hardcore RPG experience, the controls might feel weird at first, but you will get the hang of it quiet fast. The combat might seem a little hard at the start, you will feel like your hero is good for nothing, you will get beat up alot. You are weak at the start, but once you get your first proper sword and armor, you can wreck **** up!
Gothic has a basic, but good level and skill system. Though I must say it's strongly unbalanced without the proper mods installed (I will get to that later). You can do anything that is possible in a medieval world: Fight with one-handed and two-handed swords, use bows and crossbows, shoot magic bolts, summon undead creatures or let fire rain upon your enemies.

reviewText:
No one will read this review, because the game's old, but I've been really into this old gem, and wanted to give it some love.

This is the best openworld RPG I've ever played, and I've played damn near all of them. (New Vegas might come close, but is crippled by Bethesda's idiotic VATs combat.)

The game's heart is driven by a well balanced progression that feels really damn good. The satisfaction of growing from an unknown, unliked hero who runs away from wolves to a master swordsman who slays mighty beasts has never been captured so well. Sure, every game does it, but here, you feel that change viscerally, and it's damn satisfying. Starting the game not as the Savior of Mankind but a hopeless wimp might rub some people the wrong way but I can't get enough of that sort of thing.

I also very much enjoyed the main city. Very convincing as a living place. Damn near every person you meet has something going on. You could easily spend five hours getting things done in the first city alone.

The map is huge, and rewards exploration, and while games like Oblivion might also offer that, here your exploration is lended a sizable amount of tension, as you never know what might be lurking around the corner ready to tear your head off, or what treasures you might find.

Another thing I found well considered  is that each piece of gear carries a significant amount of weight. Though you may only wear a few sets of armor throughout the game, getting that first upgraded fills you with a sort of glee as you start to imagine all those difficult places you may now be able to explore. It also adds a certain element of realism to the entire experience, which aids in the immersion, which is nice in a game like this.

Choice and consequence isn't a huge part of the game, but in choosing who you ally with, there is plenty enough of that, if that's something you worry about. And many quests do give you at least one or two minor options in how you complete it.

The plot and writing aren't anything special, but the intaraction between all the guilds and your hero is well done, and it's perfect for a game like this, where your only wish is to be left alone as you run all over the map. The voice acting is stellar. Bad, but in a way that knows it's bad. So it's good!

The game obviously isn't terribly pretty, and it can be hard getting it to run on new operating systems (check the guides), but if this is your jam, then you better make some toast, because Gothic 2 is a big delicious helping of open world goodness!

6/10 IGN GOTY!!!

reviewText:
This game is one of the best action roleplaying experiences despite its age and graphics.

The world has to be one of the best designed game worlds. In the forests you are scared and quickly try to reach the nearest civilization, you find peaceful farms and behind the next corner lingers death. The world is vertical, meaning you explore hidden mountain paths and caves, wildlife, plants and enemies. Everything has a very dense atmosphere.

The inhabitants of this world have their daily routine, everybody has his own agenda. You and others have to sleep, eat and fight for survival. This feels more real than in games like Skyrim, for example. You choose your faction and this is exclusive.

There is alchemy and there are various forms of magic. All that and some unique quests make this game one of my favourite RPGs.

May Piranha Bytes develop another such immersive game.

Gothic 2 + Night of the Raven addon is definitely the best game I have ever played. The 2nd best game is probably the first Gothic. reviewText:
One of the greatest RPGs ever created.

It's not as colourful as, say, Amalur or Oblivion, it's not as gloomy as Dark Souls or Dragon's Dogma...
the (original) Gothic games managed to create their very own niche.
While not being as 'grimdark' as The Witcher or Dragon Age (which are so ridiculously ♥♥♥♥ed-up and gritty in terms of atmosphere it borders on satire), it's a very organic and believable world with lots of violence, swearing and crime, but also loyalty, good friends (DIEGO!) and great characters and stories. There are hundreds of individual characters (sadly with reused voice actors, although they at least managed to mix up their way of speaking a bit) and most of them will send you on errands, trade with you or beat your ♥♥♥ if you disrespect them.

As in the other Gothic (or Risen) games there are three main factions, one of which you'll have to join to advance in the main questline. For simplicity's sake those factions could be described as fighters, mages and something in between (Paladins)- each of them plays differently, just like you could expect from the according RPG archetypes. Each of the factions and locations comes with heaps of sidequests, all in all there are hundreds of them.

The controls are a bit outdated as it is very keyboard heavy and the combat system takes some (or lots of) getting used to as it relies almost completely on your chance to do critical hits, which of course is very low in the beginning of the game, possibly making the first few hours very difficult.
As the game is 10 years old, the visuals won't win any prizes. But the game still manages to deliver a very dense atmosphere and consistent visual feeling.
The audio on the other hand is still great. You'll get a great soundtrack (although some tracks are looped heavily), nice voice acting (I've played the German version as its the one I played when the game first was released but I read that in the English version there are renowned voice actors like Keith Szarabajka of Skyrim and Fallout:NV fame) and fitting ambiance sounds.

A few words warning though: with the expansion Night of the Raven pre-installed, the game is very hard for beginners. You'll get your hindside kicked. Again and again. But in Gothic 2 there's always a way to complete your task.
You have to kill a strong monster early in the game? Look around in town if there's someone willing to accompany you on your hunt. Or go to the local scroll merchant and buy a spell to transform yourself into a strong monster. Or you could even just try to get the monster's attention and lure it to the city guards.
Even as a Gothic veteran there are still possibilities and ways to complete a quest I never thought of.

Get this game. It can be punishing as hell, but if you love RPGs like I do, it is an experience you'll not wanna miss.

reviewText: Gothic II, just like its predecessor is an RPG that has one of the most satisfying progression system ever implemented. reviewText:
Gothic 2 is arguably my favourite RPG, and has been for many years. It features exiting fights, lots of different skills, three different 'paths' to choose from, and loads of things to discover.

First, the positive:
Gothic 2 is much smoother than Gothic 1. It's easier to use, less clunky, and merchants are easier to deal with now that gold is introduced as opposed to trading items all the time. Timing is important during fights, but so is picking your opponent.
Gothic 2 doesn't hold your hand at any stage of the game: if you make the mistake of wandering into the woodland armed with a wooden stick at level one, well, it's your funeral. The NPC's give advice, though, but you'll have to find them and ask them.
You'll also have to build your character from the ground up: you start with a little health, and a huge problem the game needs you to solve.
Levelling always feels important and vital to the game, be it your stats or your gear. The game makes every improvement you make feel valuable. This is because if you don't level up and face something stronger than you, chances are you're going to die.
All this makes playing the game incredibly rewarding. I felt genuinely satisfied every time I accomplished something, because I worked for it. Gothic won't punish you by being overly difficult: it'll just make you work.

But just in case you get too stressed grinding through the game, don't worry. After you get strong enough, you'll find some enemies easy to throw around if you skip around some of the earlier stages of the game you missed before. Destroying things that once scared the pants off you makes everything feel better. This feeling will dissapear if you accidentally stray next to a higher level enemy quite quickly though, keeping an incredibly fun cycle of victim and bully going strong until the end of the game: it never gets dull. Either you're happy and feel like a boss, or you're running for your life, and it's not something a game does for me often.

Exploration is also rewarding: loads of secrets are hidden all around the world. Some of the best items and deadliest enemies lurk where you wouldn't expect. Sometimes quest items or NPC's can be hidden in the middle of the countryside, but unlike Skyrim, you can't follow a little arrow on your compass until you come across it. Find it on your own.

As for the world itself, it's an open world, but that doesn't mean you can go anywhere you want. Higher level monsters lurk in some areas and mountains and cliffs box you in a lot of the time. This means that over a small area, there can be a lot of stuff that's hidden: under an ordinary country road could be a huge cave full of glorious, glorious loot, but at the same time, on top of the cliff to your left might be an epic monster, and you'd never even know unless you looked.

Now, the bad:
I had problems getting Gothic 2 to work on my computer. Whilst I eventually got it to work, it's a messy problem that took a patch to fix. There may be betters ways to get the game than on Steam.

Night of the Raven messed with the levelling system a lot. Before, I found the game to be difficult, but fair. Not so much now: items need much higher strength to use. This means you have to gain more levels just to use a sword you could previously use at a lower level. You also end up needing to go up even more levels to gain more stats, which was frustrating considering that I was having a hard enough time facing orcs before Night of the Raven. I didn't really appreciate the content it brought to the game either: in a world of dragons, knights, and medieval monsters, I didn't really think that pirates or aztec temples really fit. There was great nostalgia value from meeting some of the characters from Gothic 1 in the expansion, though, but I didn't feel they balanced the stuff I didn't like enough. If Gothic came without Night of the Raven, I would have much preferred that... either that or I became a bad player over these past few years (which I doubt).

Finally, the gameplay might not please some people. I spent a long time praising Gothic 2 for being difficult and rewarding, but for a more casual player, it may be a bit too brutal to get used to. The fighting system isn't the same as anything I've ever seen, and it isn't the most fluid to use. Sure, with practice, you get it, but you may not necessarily want to.

And now, my closing statement:
Gothic 2 is a classical fantasy RPG that combines some of my favourite tropes from the genre: wizards, knights, and epic, evil, hard to kill, not-at-all-watered down DRAGONS, but without making it feel too generic. The wizards (oh, I'm sorry... fire magicians) feel halfway between priests, scientists, and diplomats, and the dynamic between the paladins and the mercenaries is really well done. Choices you make have some of the most unexpected consequences making choosing a path truly unique and giving the game some great replayability.

Gothic 2 with Night of the Raven: 8/10
Gothic 2 in all it's glorious alone-ness: 10/10

And while you have to join one of three factions that exist in this world and it will not change the game plot, it will totally change the way you play (paladin, merc and mage).

reviewText:
Probably one of the greatest generic fantasy RPG's.

If only bethesda did exploration and progression like these guys.

The game design so contrasts with what you'd find in, say, skyrim or oblivion.

For starters, there's no level scaling on enemies, and there is a HUGE power difference between them. For example in the starting area, you're mostly fighting wolves, but there's also an Orc, which are NOT to be ♥♥♥♥ed with at this point. They are twice your size, and hit like a steaming train. But like a train can be sidestepped quite easily.

With perseverence and cunning, you can defeat foes that you normally shouldn't be able to, instead of just standing in place hacking away at an enemy that's designed to die by you just standing and hacking at it. If you know what I mean.

Anyways, exploration is also greatly rewarded, for example you can find a huge bag of gold coins behind some random tree (and gold is a pretty big deal in this game, its not just for buying generic longsword +2 ♥♥♥♥) or get a finely crafted sword from an expert fighter's grave that was hidden in a makeshift mausoleum inside a cave that was swarming with giant cave-dwelling carapiece-plated bugs.

Yeah it's a pretty cool game, wish more games went this route with game design, the effort in -> pay out make it so much more damn satisfying than generic bland grey difficulty all the way through.

reviewText: One of the best RPGs of all time and packaged with the Night of the Raven expansion, Gothic 2 is not for the 'Push A for Awesome' crowd.  Open world exploration, no level scaling, meaningful choice and consequence, mutually exclusive character builds, challenging enemies, and an immersive world that comes alive -- these are the hallmarks of a true old school RPG.  Melee combat requires timing rather than button mashing and even the most trivial of enemies can kick your butt at the early levels.  Of course the game has its rough points such as mediocre voice acting (English version), the occasional bug, and a somewhat poorly thought out magic system.  However any negatives are dwarfed by the game's strongpoints that deliver a solid eightyish hour experience with tons of replayability.

reviewText:
Gothic 2: Gold is a game that you either love it or leave it. If you're willing to put in the time and effort, and there will be quite the effort, you'll find a truly wonderful RPG. Gothic 2 managed to iron out a few of the rougher edges of the first Gothic. The controls have improved, the glitches are fewer and less troublesome and the technical aspects of the game are much improved. I love this game. I loved the first one, I loved Gothic 2 when it first came out in North America in 2003 and I loved Gothic 2 Night of the Raven.

Gothic 2 Gold is the proper mix of quests, exploration and combat. But make no mistake, you will die. This isn't Dark Souls, but it can be brutal. The first ten or so hours see your character, no matter which class you choose, as pretty under powered. Enemies are tough and it's not always just wolves or orcs that will kill you. The controls are a bit stiff and until you get used to them, can get you killed. There are factions to join which can somewhat dictate which abilities you can learn, but no matter which faction you choose to side with you can choose how you want to progress. If you want to be a pure fighter, with a two handed sword, fine. A mage that casts massive fire spells, sure. A thief that likes to hang back, and use his bow, not a problem. Gothic 2 lets you decide and mix and match.

Although the game play is wonderful, I found the story in the first Gothic to be superior. Gothic 2's story is still engaging and fun, but it's not exactly the most original story telling in modern gaming, but still enough to keep you going. The music is effective if not a bit repetitive. The voice acting is where Gothic 2 really shines. In no other game will you hear such a varied and bizarre mix of voice actors. Some of them are terrible, which just makes me love them more. And finally the graphics are somewhat average. Even for 2002 they were a bit dated, but the draw distance is pretty impressive, especially for a game from 12 years ago.

Gothic 2: Gold holds a special place in my heart. It may not have a million mods like Skyrim, a massive budget like Dragon Age or a sound track like GTA 5, it's still great. There aren't too many RPG's out there like the Gothic series and Gothic 2 is still my favourite in both the Gothic and Risen series. It's fun, frustrating, exhilarating, challenging, engaging and satisfying. You could easily put 60 hours into your first play through and even more on a second if you're will to explore every bit that the game has to offer. For the price it's hard to pass up.

reviewText:
FOR AMD VIDEO CARD POSSESSORS: BE AWARE
It seems that there's an issue with AMD drivers which causes a heavy FPS drop in certain parts of the world (usually near the sea).

Overall the second installment of the Gothic series is pretty good. They improved some ideas from G1 and botched a thing or two in the middle.
First, there are less bugs, but only because they removed ladders and winches. Sometimes, the game freezes and you are forced to kill it via task manager.
The game world is pretty big (the expansion in the gold edition adds a nice chunk) and there is a lot to do.

In G1 you could forge swords, albeit ♥♥♥♥♥♥. In G2 it becomes a learning path and it lets you forge the best swords in the game. They also added alchemy to craft potions, buuuut...
1- no batch crafting, one potion at a time, and it's really boring;
2- because the main ingredient of every recipe is more or less scarce, the rest will clutter your inventory with cheap herbs with low healing power.

The learning system got gimped in an attempt to prevent the player to become a murder machine like in G1, I guess. Capping the main skills is really expensive this time, not counting accessory skills. The mage path is a pain in the ♥♥♥ because of this: you have to spend points for mana, magic circles and rune crafting, maybe alchemy. You can't just have everything. Also, the merchants restock only between chapters, so if you consume every mana potion available in a chapter, you're screwed (had to cheat my way out of chapter 4 because of this).

Ranting apart, the game is actually good. Be sure to look around for tweaks like the Ironkeep Patch and the quicksave button. Also, disable the Steam overlay for this game, because it crashes with it.

reviewText:
Gothic 2 takes the world of gothic 1 and makes it bigger with a new starting map and a modified gothic 1 map for the second area, a fortress island as the final chapter and a extra map that was added with the expansion. Similar to its predecessor, it tries to make you feel like the underdog, but if you played the first game you wold find this laughable, still it is the best game of the trilogy.
You have to work your way making new friends and work up the food chain, again. This time however the game has a weird limitation that makes you over-dedicate to one class, from 1-30 any skill can be obtained with 1 LP, from 31-60 with 2LP, from 61-90 with 3LP, making some skills to expensive to improve, there are potions and tablets that can improve youțre skills, but you should keep at least until you get to 60 at that skill.
The game has some translation issues, and because of the update to the gold version some information the NPCs give you regarding leveling of some skills does not apply, even some walktroughs had the old version with the old stats.

Combat : again all combat is auto-lock, making it difficult when fighting more than one enemy, and also Random crits for the ENEMIES, cause that is fun!
melee combat is improved even though you can still use the one from G1,  however if you simply attack a enemy when they charge at you and backstep twice, you can kill most of them easy. (Chapter 3 has mages attacking you, where you simply mash the attack key.)
range combat is better than the one in G1, I mostly used it by climbing on pillars and ledges the orcs cold not get to and hit them at point blank, exploiting the AI.
magic felt opp, but because I was not a mage, I only had scrolls to compare it to, you can kill creatures you are definitely not prepared to kill very early on with the right scrolls. And also to summon a distraction for the dragons to attack while I go from behind.

reviewText: I have seen this game compared to Oblivion many times in gaming reviews and recomendations.  Its defintatly not Oblivion or even close to the quality of Oblivion.  And, unless I am missing something major in the configuration, this game is very awkward to play on a computer.  The mouse look around is extremely sluggish and I cant find a mouse speed setting anywhere in the game.  Trying to fight in this game is terribly awkward as well.  To swing a sword, you must also push a directional button-so you swing and run the direction of your swing, both at the same time, constantly over running your opponent and the extremely sluggish mouse look around makes it take forever to turn back around to face your opponent.  Meanwhile you are getting butchered.  The voice acting is really bad too and I wont comment on the poor, blocky graphics because the game is quite old so that is to be expected.  I have been considering purchasing this game for a very long time(ever since I read the first review that compared it to Oblivion).  Now I am happy that I waited for it to go on sale for only a couple of dollars.  I might have loved this game in my early gaming days when my expectations were much lower but these days I find myself not impressed by it at all.  Of course there are going to be a ton of fan boys and old school snobs who are going to freak out over my review but thats par for the course.  Having said all that, I enjoy older games as much as anyone.  If the controls were a little more PC friendly, I could put up with the bad voice acting, outdated graphics, and simplistic good and evil story line.  But the controls are NOT PC friendly.  The only mouse support is a VERY sluggish look around.  Mouse isnt even supported in the main menu or your inventory(you have to use arrow keys to select items).  If you dont mind a lot of hand work in your games and a frustrating combat/movement system then I guess go for it.  Otherwise, dont bother.

reviewText:
The Gothic games are some of the greatest RPGs out there, and Gothic 2 is the best of the series. As any good sequel should, Gothic 2 improves upon the original and adds even more.

The Gothic series is known for an immersive open-world atmosphere, unforgiving combat, and interesting characters; Gothic 2 has all of this in spades. In addition, this game adds some crafting elements (notably alchemy and runes/spells, with a little smithing thrown in) that were glaringly missing from the original. The world is roughly 3 times larger than the first (4 times including the content added by Night of the Raven) and is full of little nooks containing treasures, traps and monsters to satisfy your itch to explore.

The game takes place shortly after the events of the first title and involves many of the original characters (and some familiar places). I highly recommend playing the original Gothic first, because it'll make the sequel that much more enjoyable when you encounter them.

Whether you're leveling up stats/skills or interacting with an NPC, you'll often have to make decisions that will impact the rest of the game. Character progression is slow but rewarding, though you'll feel like there's not enough skill points to go around. This is intentional so that you're encouraged to focus on a particular style of play and is further emphasized by how the game handles factions. If in doubt, take some time to consider those decisions (or at least save in an alternate slot).

While Gothic 2 is an amazing title, it's not perfect. I recall a quest involving Lares and Vatras that was very buggy and could potentially ruin your story progression entirely. The bosses are challenging, but are pretty much identical. Diego (a main character from the first game) is mostly an annoying and generic NPC this time around and was voiced by someone else. Being an older game, it's often a hassle to get running on modern PCs (there are guides that help most people) and even then is prone to crashing at the end of several cutscenes (skipping them seems to work, though you'll have to view them elsewhere). Thankfully, Gothic 2 is still very much worth playing despite these flaws.

I'm a bit of an RPG fanatic in general, and I can definitely appreciate the classics such as Baldur's Gate and Morrowind, and, in some cases, I can end up appreciating the classics more than I can the new blood. This is one of those cases.

Before I get started, allow me to state that this game has an extremely unforgiving early game that neither of the titles in the paragraph above hold a candle to in terms of difficulty. It is unforgiving and you will die. You will die a lot. You will die so many times, actually, that you just stop getting mad all together. Of course, part of the charm in the classic RPGs is the difficulty, and Gothic II certainly doesn't skim on that. It is as deep, complex, and difficult as even any RPG out there.

The architecture and design is clearly inspired by medevil Germany, especially the houses and buildings and whatnot, which are almost spot on for not only that time period but in some cases, modern German architecture. I found that to be pretty fun, admittedly. It really goes great with Sour Cream & Onion flavored potato chips. There are a lot of quest and all of the dialogue is voiced, and while the voice acting can be a bit laughable at times the dialogue itself is really great. Keep in mind this game was ported to the English language, and voice acting in ports is usually not very great. This time it was just us English speakers catching the short end of the stick for once, because I hear the voice acting in the original language is pretty dope. The direct dialogue itself is still pretty amazing, though. Very immerse dialogue in conversations that involve your character and you pick which way the conversations lead and whatnot, so I find that to be pretty fun.

Gothic 2 with the add-on The Night Of The Raven is truly a masterpiece of an rpg. The story, the voiceacting, the melee fighting mechanics, the vast and diverse world is one of a kind. Gothic 1 should be played before this game, so you wont have trouble understanding the story ( and gothic 1 is fantastic game as well ).

Pros
- This game is a true open-world rpg. You can visit the vast majority of places in the world without story developing into those regions
- The melee fighting mechanic is very well constructed. The combos are really fun execute. The AI meelefighters are also masterfully done. You will understand in a very short time, that you are facing a true blademaster. The parries, dodges and combos the enemies can do makes the fighting experience something beyond many rpg games i have played.
- The magic in the game is diverse. Healing, summoning, teleportation, elemental, status effect you have everything in this game. The AI mages usually use low level spells, but sometimes you encounter your usual enemy mage casting one the strongest fire spells if you allow him to execute the spell in time.
- The story is fantastic. Very well written, very well coordinated through npcs, augmented with side-quests helping you get through the main story.
- The side quest are what makes this game on the best in its time.
- The voice acting is fantastic ( especially the german)
- The integration of the gothic 1 characters is smoothly done. They fit right in where you will find them here in gothic 2
- The world is wonderfully constructed, each new region has a center plaza to rotate easily between places of importance. Different terrain in nearly all the new places you encounter. Vast number of monsters. Huge number of npcs. The npcs with no names ( eg. a novice) has speech option, where he or she will give a different responses to the different events happening in the world of khorinis at that time
- Replayable through different faction selections.
- Fantastic world and boss music

Cons
- Minor logic mistake with npc equipments
- Playing as a mage in add-on is very hard. This is very sad, because some of the add-on introduced spells are very fun to use ( the normal G2 mage is still fine)
- Some of the boss battles are not working properly, the patterns leave open a lot of abuses for archers and mages to exploit.
- There are still some bugs for unlimited gold if you have the time to do it multiple times. ( nothing gamebreaking )

Overall i give this game a 10/10
One of the best rpg ever made, the best open-world rpg in my opinion and it should on every top x rpg list for the next 50+ years . And yes i love this game ..

reviewText:
The Gothic games are some of the greatest RPGs out there, and Gothic 2 is the best of the series. As any good sequel should, Gothic 2 improves upon the original and adds even more.

The Gothic series is known for an immersive open-world atmosphere, unforgiving combat, and interesting characters; Gothic 2 has all of this in spades. In addition, this game adds some crafting elements (notably alchemy and runes/spells, with a little smithing thrown in) that were glaringly missing from the original. The world is roughly 3 times larger than the first (4 times including the content added by Night of the Raven) and is full of little nooks containing treasures, traps and monsters to satisfy your itch to explore.

The game takes place shortly after the events of the first title and involves many of the original characters (and some familiar places). I highly recommend playing the original Gothic first, because it'll make the sequel that much more enjoyable when you encounter them.

Whether you're leveling up stats/skills or interacting with an NPC, you'll often have to make decisions that will impact the rest of the game. Character progression is slow but rewarding, though you'll feel like there's not enough skill points to go around. This is intentional so that you're encouraged to focus on a particular style of play and is further emphasized by how the game handles factions. If in doubt, take some time to consider those decisions (or at least save in an alternate slot).

While Gothic 2 is an amazing title, it's not perfect. I recall a quest involving Lares and Vatras that was very buggy and could potentially ruin your story progression entirely. The bosses are challenging, but are pretty much identical. Diego (a main character from the first game) is mostly an annoying and generic NPC this time around and was voiced by someone else. Being an older game, it's often a hassle to get running on modern PCs (there are guides that help most people) and even then is prone to crashing at the end of several cutscenes (skipping them seems to work, though you'll have to view them elsewhere). Thankfully, Gothic 2 is still very much worth playing despite these flaws.
